events.title: Daytime Dig Preparations, Dreams of Treasure, and Tom's Marriage Plans
detailed_summary: Huck expresses his contentment with the idea of finding a hundred dollars, stating he has no need for diamonds.
Tom, however, insists he wouldn't pass up diamonds, highlighting their significant value.
They discuss the rarity and worth of diamonds, with Tom remarking that kings possess them in abundance.
A humorous misunderstanding arises about kings 'hopping around,' which Tom quickly clarifies.
Tom explains that kings typically have only a single given name.
Huck finds this peculiar and undesirable, comparing it to the naming conventions for Black individuals at the time.
Huck redirects the conversation, asking Tom where they will begin their digging.
Tom suggests they start with an old dead-limb tree located on the hill on the other side of Still-House branch, to which Huck agrees.
They procure a damaged pickaxe and a shovel and embark on a three-mile walk to the chosen spot.
Arriving hot and out of breath, they rest in the shade of a nearby elm tree and have a smoke.
Tom expresses his enjoyment of the adventure, and Huck concurs.
Tom then asks Huck how he plans to use his share of any treasure they might find.
Huck outlines his desires: daily pie and soda, and attending every circus that comes to town, envisioning a very merry time.
Tom questions whether Huck intends to save any of his potential fortune.
Huck dismisses the idea of saving, fearing his absent father would return and confiscate any accumulated money.
Huck then asks Tom about his own plans for the treasure.
Tom reveals his intentions: to buy a new drum, a genuine sword, a red necktie, a bull pup, and to get married.
Huck is visibly shocked by Tom's plan to marry.
Tom confirms his intention.
Huck exclaims that Tom must not be in his right mind, calling marriage the most foolish thing he could do and citing his own parents' constant fighting as an example.
Tom confidently states that the girl he plans to marry will not be prone to fighting.
Huck expresses skepticism, opining that all girls are essentially the same and will 'comb a body' (nag or scold), advising Tom to reconsider.
Huck asks for the girl's name.
Tom defers answering, promising to tell him at a later time.
Huck resigns himself to this, but expresses concern that Tom's marriage will leave him feeling more alone than ever.
Tom reassures Huck that he won't be alone and can come live with him and his future wife, then urges him to get up so they can begin digging.

events.text_segment:
“That’s bully. Plenty bully enough for me. Just you gimme the hundred dollars and I don’t want no di’monds.”
“All right. But I bet you I ain’t going to throw off on di’monds. Some of ’em’s worth twenty dollars apiece—there ain’t any, hardly, but’s worth six bits or a dollar.”
“No! Is that so?”
“Cert’nly—anybody’ll tell you so. Hain’t you ever seen one, Huck?”
“Not as I remember.”
“Oh, kings have slathers of them.”
“Well, I don’ know no kings, Tom.”
“I reckon you don’t. But if you was to go to Europe you’d see a raft of ’em hopping around.”
“Do they hop?”
“Hop?—your granny! No!”
“Well, what did you say they did, for?”
“Shucks, I only meant you’d see ’em—not hopping, of course—what do they want to hop for?—but I mean you’d just see ’em—scattered around, you know, in a kind of a general way. Like that old humpbacked Richard.”
“Richard? What’s his other name?”
“He didn’t have any other name. Kings don’t have any but a given name.”
“No?”
“But they don’t.”
“Well, if they like it, Tom, all right; but I don’t want to be a king and have only just a given name, like a nigger. But say—where you going to dig first?”
“Well, I don’t know. S’pose we tackle that old dead-limb tree on the hill t’other side of Still-House branch?”
“I’m agreed.”
So they got a crippled pick and a shovel, and set out on their three-mile tramp. They arrived hot and panting, and threw themselves down in the shade of a neighboring elm to rest and have a smoke.
“I like this,” said Tom.
“So do I.”
“Say, Huck, if we find a treasure here, what you going to do with your share?”
“Well, I’ll have pie and a glass of soda every day, and I’ll go to every circus that comes along. I bet I’ll have a gay time.”
“Well, ain’t you going to save any of it?”
“Save it? What for?”
“Why, so as to have something to live on, by and by.”
“Oh, that ain’t any use. Pap would come back to thish-yer town some day and get his claws on it if I didn’t hurry up, and I tell you he’d clean it out pretty quick. What you going to do with yourn, Tom?”
“I’m going to buy a new drum, and a sure’nough sword, and a red necktie and a bull pup, and get married.”
“Married!”
“That’s it.”
“Tom, you—why, you ain’t in your right mind.”
“Wait—you’ll see.”
“Well, that’s the foolishest thing you could do. Look at pap and my mother. Fight! Why, they used to fight all the time. I remember, mighty well.”
“That ain’t anything. The girl I’m going to marry won’t fight.”
“Tom, I reckon they’re all alike. They’ll all comb a body. Now you better think ’bout this awhile. I tell you you better. What’s the name of the gal?”
“It ain’t a gal at all—it’s a girl.”
“It’s all the same, I reckon; some says gal, some says girl—both’s right, like enough. Anyway, what’s her name, Tom?”
“I’ll tell you some time—not now.”
“All right—that’ll do. Only if you get married I’ll be more lonesomer than ever.”
“No you won’t. You’ll come and live with me. Now stir out of this and we’ll go to digging.”

events.title: Fruitless Daytime Digging and a Crucial Realization
detailed_summary: The boys dig energetically for half an hour but find nothing.
They toil for another half hour with the same lack of results.
Huck asks if treasure is always buried so deeply.
Tom replies that it's not always, or even generally, buried deep, and suggests they might be in the wrong location.
They choose a new spot and start digging again.
The work feels somewhat tedious, but they continue to make progress, digging in silence for a while.
Eventually, Huck leans on his shovel, wipes sweat from his brow, and asks where Tom plans to dig next.
Tom suggests they might try the old tree on Cardiff Hill, behind the widow's house.
Huck agrees it sounds like a good spot but voices concern that the widow might claim any treasure found, as it's on her land.
Tom dismisses this worry, confidently stating that discovered treasure belongs to the finder, regardless of whose land it is on.
This explanation satisfies Huck, and they resume their work.
After a while, Huck exclaims that they must be in the wrong place again and asks Tom for his opinion.
Tom finds the situation puzzling and suggests that witches might be interfering with their efforts.
Huck scoffs at this, reminding Tom that witches lack power during the daytime.
Tom acknowledges his oversight and then has a sudden insight: they need to find where the tree limb's shadow falls at midnight to locate the correct digging spot.
Huck bemoans their wasted effort and the necessity of returning at night, noting the long distance.
Tom insists they must return that very night, fearing that if someone discovers their current dig holes, the treasure's presence will be revealed.
Huck agrees to come back and signal Tom by meowing.
Tom suggests they hide their tools in nearby bushes.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “All right. Let’s hide the tools in the bushes.”

events.text_segment:
They worked and sweated for half an hour. No result. They toiled another halfhour. Still no result. Huck said:
“Do they always bury it as deep as this?”
“Sometimes—not always. Not generally. I reckon we haven’t got the right place.”
So they chose a new spot and began again. The labor dragged a little, but still they made progress. They pegged away in silence for some time. Finally Huck leaned on his shovel, swabbed the beaded drops from his brow with his sleeve, and said:
“Where you going to dig next, after we get this one?”
“I reckon maybe we’ll tackle the old tree that’s over yonder on Cardiff Hill back of the widow’s.”
“I reckon that’ll be a good one. But won’t the widow take it away from us, Tom? It’s on her land.”
“She take it away! Maybe she’d like to try it once. Whoever finds one of these hid treasures, it belongs to him. It don’t make any difference whose land it’s on.”
That was satisfactory. The work went on. By and by Huck said:
“Blame it, we must be in the wrong place again. What do you think?”
“It is mighty curious, Huck. I don’t understand it. Sometimes witches interfere. I reckon maybe that’s what’s the trouble now.”
“Shucks! Witches ain’t got no power in the daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. I didn’t think of that. Oh, I know what the matter is! What a blamed lot of fools we are! You got to find out where the shadow of the limb falls at midnight, and that’s where you dig!”
“Then consound it, we’ve fooled away all this work for nothing. Now hang it all, we got to come back in the night. It’s an awful long way. Can you get out?”
“I bet I will. We’ve got to do it tonight, too, because if somebody sees these holes they’ll know in a minute what’s here and they’ll go for it.”
“Well, I’ll come around and maow tonight.”
“All right. Let’s hide the tools in the bushes.”

events.title: The Spooky Nighttime Dig and Growing Fear
detailed_summary: The boys returned to the digging site that night around the agreed-upon time.
They sat quietly in the shadows, waiting for midnight.
The location felt isolated, and the hour was made more solemn by old superstitions.
Eerie sounds surrounded them: whispers in the rustling leaves, the distant baying of a hound, and an owl's mournful call, suggesting lurking spirits and ghosts.
The boys were subdued by the atmosphere and spoke very little.
When they judged it to be midnight, they identified where the shadow of the limb fell and commenced digging.
Their hopes began to rise, their interest intensified, and they worked diligently.
The hole grew deeper, but each time their pickaxe struck something, causing a hopeful jump, it was merely a stone or a piece of wood, leading to renewed disappointment.
Finally, Tom conceded that their efforts were futile and they were mistaken again.
Huck argued that they couldn't be wrong, as they had marked the shadow's position accurately.
Tom pointed out another potential error: they had only estimated the time, which might have been too early or too late for the correct shadow.
Huck, disheartened, dropped his shovel.
He agreed this was the issue and declared they had to abandon this spot, finding it impossible to determine the correct time.
Huck also expressed his intense fear of the nighttime setting, with its perceived witches and ghosts, feeling constantly watched and too afraid to look around for fear of what he might see.
Tom admitted he felt much the same way.
Tom added a chilling detail: treasure buried under a tree is often guarded by a dead man.
Huck was terrified by this notion, exclaiming his aversion to disturbing the dead.
Tom agreed, imagining a skull emerging and speaking, which further horrified Huck.
Both boys confessed to feeling extremely uncomfortable.
Huck proposed they give up on that location and try somewhere else.
Tom agreed it was probably for the best.
Huck then asked what their next option would be.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The boys were there that night, about the appointed time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “What’ll it be?”

events.text_segment:
The boys were there that night, about the appointed time. They sat in the shadow waiting. It was a lonely place, and an hour made solemn by old traditions. Spirits whispered in the rustling leaves, ghosts lurked in the murky nooks, the deep baying of a hound floated up out of the distance, an owl answered with his sepulchral note. The boys were subdued by these solemnities, and talked little. By and by they judged that twelve had come; they marked where the shadow fell, and began to dig. Their hopes commenced to rise. Their interest grew stronger, and their industry kept pace with it. The hole deepened and still deepened, but every time their hearts jumped to hear the pick strike upon something, they only suffered a new disappointment. It was only a stone or a chunk. At last Tom said:
“It ain’t any use, Huck, we’re wrong again.”
“Well, but we can’t be wrong. We spotted the shadder to a dot.”
“I know it, but then there’s another thing.”
“What’s that?”
“Why, we only guessed at the time. Like enough it was too late or too early.”
Huck dropped his shovel.
“That’s it,” said he. “That’s the very trouble. We got to give this one up. We can’t ever tell the right time, and besides this kind of thing’s too awful, here this time of night with witches and ghosts a-fluttering around so. I feel as if something’s behind me all the time;  and I’m afeard to turn around, becuz maybe there’s others in front a-waiting for a chance. I been creeping all over, ever since I got here.”
“Well, I’ve been pretty much so, too, Huck. They most always put in a dead man when they bury a treasure under a tree, to look out for it.”
“Lordy!”
“Yes, they do. I’ve always heard that.”
“Tom, I don’t like to fool around much where there’s dead people. A body’s bound to get into trouble with ’em, sure.”
“I don’t like to stir ’em up, either. S’pose this one here was to stick his skull out and say something!”
“Don’t Tom! It’s awful.”
“Well, it just is. Huck, I don’t feel comfortable a bit.”
“Say, Tom, let’s give this place up, and try somewheres else.”
“All right, I reckon we better.”
“What’ll it be?”

events.title: The Haunted House as the Next Target and Cautious Retreat
detailed_summary: After a period of reflection, Tom announced his new idea: the haunted house.
Huck immediately voiced his strong aversion to haunted houses, considering them far worse than places with dead bodies.

He elaborated that while dead people might talk, ghosts were more terrifying due to their silent, sudden appearances, such as sliding around in shrouds or peeking over one's shoulder and gritting their teeth.
Tom countered that ghosts are only active at night, so they could safely dig at the haunted house during the daytime.
Huck conceded this point but reminded Tom that people generally avoid the haunted house at all times, day or night.
Tom attributed this general avoidance to the fact that a man had been murdered there, but claimed that no regular ghosts had been seen, only occasional blue lights near the windows at night.
Huck argued that blue lights are a sure sign of a nearby ghost, as only ghosts use them.
Tom agreed with this logic but reiterated that since ghosts don't appear in the daytime, there was no reason for them to be afraid.
Huck reluctantly consented to try the haunted house, though he expressed his feeling that they were taking a significant chance.
By this point, the boys had begun their descent from the hill.

The narrative describes the appearance of the 'haunted' house below them in the moonlit valley: utterly isolated, its fences long gone, weeds choking the doorsteps, the chimney in ruins, window-sashes empty, and a section of the roof caved in.
The boys paused, observing the house for a while, half-anticipating the sight of a blue light flickering past a window.
Then, speaking in low tones appropriate for the time and circumstances, they decided to take a wide path around the haunted house, heading homeward through the woods at the back of Cardiff Hill.

“The ha’nted house. That’s it!”
“Blame it, I don’t like ha’nted houses, Tom. Why, they’re a dern sight worse’n dead people. I couldn’t stand such a thing as that, Tom—nobody could.”
“Yes, but, Huck, ghosts don’t travel around only at night. They won’t hender us from digging there in the daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. But you know mighty well people don’t go about that ha’nted house in the day nor the night.”
“Well, that’s mostly because they don’t like to go where a man’s been murdered, anyway—but nothing’s ever been seen around that house except in the night—just some blue lights slipping by the windows—no regular ghosts.”
“Well, where you see one of them blue lights flickering around, Tom, you can bet there’s a ghost mighty close behind it. It stands to reason. Becuz you know that they don’t anybody but ghosts use ’em.”
“Yes, that’s so. But anyway they don’t come around in the daytime, so what’s the use of our being afeard?”
“Well, all right. We’ll tackle the ha’nted house if you say so—but I reckon it’s taking chances.”

events.title: Friday Superstition and Postponement of Treasure Hunt
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck arrive at the dead tree near the haunted house, intending to retrieve their tools for digging.
Huck suddenly recalls that it is Friday, a day considered unlucky.
Tom concurs with Huck's superstition, acknowledging the potential danger of undertaking their planned activities on such a day.
Huck then mentions a disquieting dream he had about rats the previous night.
Tom interprets the dream: rats not fighting signifies surrounding trouble, advising caution.
They decide to abandon their haunted house plans for the day and engage in playing Robin Hood instead.
Tom proceeds to explain the character of Robin Hood to Huck, portraying him as a heroic figure who robbed the wealthy but aided the impoverished.
Huck expresses his admiration for Robin Hood and his lifestyle.
Tom further embellishes Robin Hood's legend, highlighting his exceptional combat and archery skills.
When Huck inquires about a 'yew bow,' Tom admits his ignorance but dismisses it as unimportant for their game.

The boys spend the remainder of the afternoon engrossed in their Robin Hood play, though they occasionally cast hopeful glances towards the haunted house, anticipating their activities there on the morrow.

events.text_segment:
About noon the next day the boys arrived at the dead tree; they had come for their tools. Tom was impatient to go to the haunted house; Huck was measurably so, also—but suddenly said:
“Lookyhere, Tom, do you know what day it is?”
Tom mentally ran over the days of the week, and then quickly lifted his eyes with a startled look in them—
“My! I never once thought of it, Huck!”
“Well, I didn’t neither, but all at once it popped onto me that it was Friday.”
“Blame it, a body can’t be too careful, Huck. We might ’a’ got into an awful scrape, tackling such a thing on a Friday.”
“Might! Better say we would! There’s some lucky days, maybe, but Friday ain’t.”
“Any fool knows that. I don’t reckon you was the first that found it out, Huck.”
“Well, I never said I was, did I? And Friday ain’t all, neither. I had a rotten bad dream last night—dreampt about rats.”
“No! Sure sign of trouble. Did they fight?”
“No.”
“Well, that’s good, Huck. When they don’t fight it’s only a sign that there’s trouble around, you know. All we got to do is to look mighty sharp and keep out of it. We’ll drop this thing for today, and play. Do you know Robin Hood, Huck?”
“No. Who’s Robin Hood?”
“Why, he was one of the greatest men that was ever in England—and the best. He was a robber.”
“Cracky, I wisht I was. Who did he rob?”
“Only sheriffs and bishops and rich people and kings, and such like. But he never bothered the poor. He loved ’em. He always divided up with ’em perfectly square.”
“Well, he must ’a’ been a brick.”
“I bet you he was, Huck. Oh, he was the noblest man that ever was. They ain’t any such men now, I can tell you. He could lick any man in England, with one hand tied behind him; and he could take his yew bow and plug a ten-cent piece every time, a mile and a half.”
“What’s a yew bow?”
“I don’t know. It’s some kind of a bow, of course. And if he hit that dime only on the edge he would set down and cry—and curse. But we’ll play Robin Hood—it’s nobby fun. I’ll learn you.”
“I’m agreed.”
So they played Robin Hood all the afternoon, now and then casting a yearning eye down upon the haunted house and passing a remark about the morrow’s prospects and possibilities there. As the sun began to sink into the west they took their way homeward athwart the long shadows of the trees and soon were buried from sight in the forests of Cardiff Hill.

events.title: Return to the Haunted House and Cautious Initial Exploration
detailed_summary: On Saturday, the boys return to the dead tree.
After a smoke and conversation, they undertake a brief and unfruitful dig in their previous excavation site, persuaded by Tom's assertion that treasures are often found by those who almost give up.
Content that they have fulfilled the obligations of treasure-hunting, they proceed towards the haunted house.
Upon reaching the house, its profound silence under the hot sun and its desolate, lonely appearance momentarily frighten them.

They cautiously approach the door and peer inside, observing a weed-filled, floorless room, unplastered walls, an old fireplace, empty window frames, a dilapidated staircase, and pervasive, neglected cobwebs.
With heightened senses and pounding hearts, they enter softly, speaking in whispers and remaining alert for any sound, prepared for a swift retreat.
As they grow more accustomed to the surroundings, their fears diminish, and they begin to examine the house with critical interest, admiring their own daring.
Their next objective is to explore the upstairs, a decision that feels like severing their escape route.
After mutual encouragement, they store their tools in a corner and ascend the stairs.
The upper floor exhibits the same level of decay as below; a closet that hinted at mystery reveals nothing.
With their courage now firm, they are on the verge of descending to commence their digging when Tom abruptly signals for quiet.

On Saturday, shortly after noon, the boys were at the dead tree again. They had a smoke and a chat in the shade, and then dug a little in their last hole, not with great hope, but merely because Tom said there were so many cases where people had given up a treasure after getting down within six inches of it, and then somebody else had come along and turned it up with a single thrust of a shovel. The thing failed this time, however, so the boys shouldered their tools and went away feeling that they had not trifled with fortune, but had fulfilled all the requirements that belong to the business of treasure-hunting.
When they reached the haunted house there was something so weird and grisly about the dead silence that reigned there under the baking sun, and something so depressing about the loneliness and desolation of the place, that they were afraid, for a moment, to venture in. Then they crept to the door and took a trembling peep. They saw a weedgrown, floorless room, unplastered, an ancient fireplace, vacant windows, a ruinous staircase; and here, there, and everywhere hung ragged and abandoned cobwebs. They presently entered, softly, with quickened pulses, talking in whispers, ears alert to catch the slightest sound, and muscles tense and ready for instant retreat.
In a little while familiarity modified their fears and they gave the place a critical and interested examination, rather admiring their own boldness, and wondering at it, too. Next they wanted to look upstairs. This was something like cutting off retreat, but they got to daring each other, and of course there could be but one result—they threw their tools into a corner and made the ascent. Up there were the same signs of decay. In one corner they found a closet that promised mystery, but the promise was a fraud—there was nothing in it. Their courage was up now and well in hand. They were about to go down and begin work when—

events.title: The Arrival and Unmasking of Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Tom urgently signals Huck to be quiet, having heard a sound.
Huck becomes terrified as Tom confirms the noise and indicates that people are approaching the door.
The boys quickly lie down on the floor, using knotholes in the planks to observe, consumed by fear.
Tom whispers that the individuals have arrived and warns Huck to remain absolutely silent.
Two men enter the house. The boys recognize one as the 'deaf and dumb Spaniard' they had seen in town previously; the other man is unfamiliar, with a ragged and unkempt appearance.
The 'Spaniard' is distinctively dressed in a serape, with bushy white whiskers, long white hair flowing from under his sombrero, and green goggles.
As the men enter, the unknown companion is speaking in a low voice; they sit on the ground near the door, and he continues his remarks, becoming less guarded.
The companion expresses concern that their plan is dangerous.
To the boys' astonishment, the 'deaf and dumb' Spaniard retorts, calling the companion a 'Milksop' for thinking it dangerous.
The voice causes the boys to gasp and tremble; they realize it is Injun Joe.
Following a tense silence, Injun Joe speaks, dismissing the current plan's danger by comparing it to a less successful venture up the river.
The companion argues the previous situation was different due to its isolated location.
Injun Joe counters by pointing out the risk of being seen entering the haunted house in broad daylight.
He reveals he had intended to leave the previous day but was prevented by the sight of 'those infernal boys' (Tom and Huck) playing nearby on the hill, in full view.
Hearing themselves mentioned, Tom and Huck are further terrified, appreciating their luck in postponing their visit due to Friday, and now wishing they had delayed it for a year.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They wished in their hearts they had waited a year.

events.text_segment:
“Sh!” said Tom.
“What is it?” whispered Huck, blanching with fright.
“Sh!... There!... Hear it?”
“Yes!... Oh, my! Let’s run!”
“Keep still! Don’t you budge! They’re coming right toward the door.”
The boys stretched themselves upon the floor with their eyes to knotholes in the planking, and lay waiting, in a misery of fear.
“They’ve stopped.... No—coming.... Here they are. Don’t whisper another word, Huck. My goodness, I wish I was out of this!”
Two men entered. Each boy said to himself: “There’s the old deaf and dumb Spaniard that’s been about town once or twice lately—never saw t’other man before.”
“T’other” was a ragged, unkempt creature, with nothing very pleasant in his face. The Spaniard was wrapped in a serape; he had bushy white whiskers; long white hair flowed from under his sombrero, and he wore green goggles. When they came in, “t’other” was talking in a low voice; they sat down on the ground, facing the door, with their backs to the wall, and the speaker continued his remarks. His manner became less guarded and his words more distinct as he proceeded:
“No,” said he, “I’ve thought it all over, and I don’t like it. It’s dangerous.”
“Dangerous!” grunted the “deaf and dumb” Spaniard—to the vast surprise of the boys. “Milksop!”
This voice made the boys gasp and quake. It was Injun Joe’s! There was silence for some time. Then Joe said:
“What’s any more dangerous than that job up yonder—but nothing’s come of it.”
“That’s different. Away up the river so, and not another house about. ’Twon’t ever be known that we tried, anyway, long as we didn’t succeed.”
“Well, what’s more dangerous than coming here in the daytime!—anybody would suspicion us that saw us.”
“I know that. But there warn’t any other place as handy after that fool of a job. I want to quit this shanty. I wanted to yesterday, only it warn’t any use trying to stir out of here, with those infernal boys playing over there on the hill right in full view.”
“Those infernal boys” quaked again under the inspiration of this remark, and thought how lucky it was that they had remembered it was Friday and concluded to wait a day. They wished in their hearts they had waited a year.

As they entered, the second man was quietly speaking; they sat facing the door, backs to the wall, and the man kept talking, growing bolder and more audible.
"No," he said, "I've thought it over, and I don't like it. It's risky."
"Risky!" scoffed the "deaf and mute" Spaniard, shocking the boys. "Coward!"
The voice made the boys shudder—it was Injun Joe! The room fell silent briefly, then Joe said:
"What's more dangerous than that job upriver? Nothing's happened."
"That's not the same. That spot's way up the river, no houses around. Even if we tried and failed, no one would ever know."
"Still, coming here in daylight is riskier! Anyone seeing us would suspect something."
"I know. But nowhere else was as handy after that blunder. I wanted to leave this place yesterday, but it was useless—those darn kids were out playing on the hill where they could see us."
The boys trembled again, realizing how lucky they were to have decided to wait a day because it was Friday. They secretly wished they'd waited even longer.

events.title: Injun Joe's Plans and the Boys' Aborted Escape Attempt
detailed_summary: Injun Joe and his companion share some food.
After a period of thoughtful silence, Injun Joe outlines his instructions: the companion is to return up the river and await contact.
Injun Joe himself plans to survey the town once more to prepare for their 'dangerous' job, after which they will both depart for Texas.
The companion finds this arrangement satisfactory.
Both men begin to feel sleepy, and Injun Joe declares his exhaustion, assigning his companion the duty of keeping watch while he sleeps.
Injun Joe lies down among the weeds and soon starts snoring.
His companion rouses him a couple of times until his snoring subsides.
Presently, the designated watcher also begins to doze off, his head drooping, until both men are snoring.
The boys, hidden above, take a relieved breath, sensing an opportunity for escape.
Tom whispers to Huck that this is their chance to flee.
Huck, however, is paralyzed by fear, believing he would die if the men were to awaken.
Despite Tom's urging, Huck refuses to move. Eventually, Tom slowly and quietly rises, intending to escape alone.
His very first step produces a loud creak from the unstable floorboards, causing him to sink back down, almost overcome with fright.
He abandons any further escape attempts.
The boys remain concealed, enduring what feels like an eternity, until they are relieved to observe the sun finally beginning to set.

events.text_segment:
The two men got out some food and made a luncheon. After a long and thoughtful silence, Injun Joe said:
“Look here, lad—you go back up the river where you belong. Wait there till you hear from me. I’ll take the chances on dropping into this town just once more, for a look. We’ll do that ‘dangerous’ job after I’ve spied around a little and think things look well for it. Then for Texas! We’ll leg it together!”
This was satisfactory. Both men presently fell to yawning, and Injun Joe said:
“I’m dead for sleep! It’s your turn to watch.”
He curled down in the weeds and soon began to snore. His comrade stirred him once or twice and he became quiet. Presently the watcher began to nod; his head drooped lower and lower, both men began to snore now.
The boys drew a long, grateful breath. Tom whispered:
“Now’s our chance—come!”
Huck said:
“I can’t—I’d die if they was to wake.”
Tom urged—Huck held back. At last Tom rose slowly and softly, and started alone. But the first step he made wrung such a hideous creak from the crazy floor that he sank down almost dead with fright. He never made a second attempt. The boys lay there counting the dragging moments till it seemed to them that time must be done and eternity growing gray; and then they were grateful to note that at last the sun was setting.

events.title: Discovery of Hidden Silver and a Greater Treasure of Gold
detailed_summary: One of the snoring sounds stops; Injun Joe sits up and surveys his surroundings.
He smiles grimly at his still-sleeping comrade, then rouses him with his foot, commenting on his poor watchfulness but noting that nothing untoward has occurred.
The startled companion asks if he had fallen asleep.
Injun Joe confirms this and states it's almost time for them to depart, then questions what to do with their remaining 'swag'.
The companion suggests leaving it in the house as they've done previously, mentioning it amounts to six hundred and fifty dollars in silver.
Injun Joe initially concurs but then reconsiders, worrying about potential delays before his 'job' and the risk of accidents, proposing they bury the silver deeply for safety.

His companion agrees and retrieves a bag of coins from beneath a hearthstone, taking a portion for himself and Injun Joe before handing the bag to Injun Joe, who is preparing to dig with his bowie-knife.
The boys, forgetting all fear, watch with rapt attention and immense excitement, astounded by the sum of money and the seemingly effortless way treasure is being handled.
While digging, Injun Joe's knife strikes something solid.
He initially thinks it's a piece of rotten wood, then realizes it's a box.
He manages to create an opening in the box, reaches inside, and pulls out his hand, exclaiming that it contains money.
Both men inspect the handful of coins and discover they are gold.
The boys hidden above are just as thrilled and delighted by this discovery as the men below.

events.text_segment:
Now one snore ceased. Injun Joe sat up, stared around—smiled grimly upon his comrade, whose head was drooping upon his knees—stirred him up with his foot and said:
“Here! You’re a watchman, ain’t you! All right, though—nothing’s happened.”
“My! have I been asleep?”
“Oh, partly, partly. Nearly time for us to be moving, pard. What’ll we do with what little swag we’ve got left?”
“I don’t know—leave it here as we’ve always done, I reckon. No use to take it away till we start south. Six hundred and fifty in silver’s something to carry.”
“Well—all right—it won’t matter to come here once more.”
“No—but I’d say come in the night as we used to do—it’s better.”
“Yes: but look here; it may be a good while before I get the right chance at that job; accidents might happen; ’tain’t in such a very good place; we’ll just regularly bury it—and bury it deep.”
“Good idea,” said the comrade, who walked across the room, knelt down, raised one of the rearward hearth-stones and took out a bag that jingled pleasantly. He subtracted from it twenty or thirty dollars for himself and as much for Injun Joe, and passed the bag to the latter, who was on his knees in the corner, now, digging with his bowie-knife.
The boys forgot all their fears, all their miseries in an instant. With gloating eyes they watched every movement. Luck!—the splendor of it was beyond all imagination! Six hundred dollars was money enough to make half a dozen boys rich! Here was treasure-hunting under the happiest auspices—there would not be any bothersome uncertainty as to where to dig. They nudged each other every moment—eloquent nudges and easily understood, for they simply meant—“Oh, but ain’t you glad now we’re here!”
Joe’s knife struck upon something.
“Hello!” said he.
“What is it?” said his comrade.
“Half-rotten plank—no, it’s a box, I believe. Here—bear a hand and we’ll see what it’s here for. Never mind, I’ve broke a hole.”
He reached his hand in and drew it out—
“Man, it’s money!”
The two men examined the handful of coins. They were gold. The boys above were as excited as themselves, and as delighted.

events.title: Injun Joe's Revenge Motive and Suspicion Over Fresh Tools
detailed_summary: Injun Joe's comrade suggests they process the newfound gold quickly, recalling he saw an old rusty pickaxe nearby.
He fetches the pickaxe and a shovel, which happen to be the boys' tools.
Injun Joe takes the pick, inspects it with a critical eye, shakes his head and mutters before starting to dig out the box.
The iron-bound box, though aged and damaged, is soon unearthed.
The men gaze at the treasure, which amounts to thousands of dollars, in blissful silence.
The companion notes the old rumor that Murrel's gang frequented the area, and Injun Joe concurs, saying the treasure looks like it could be theirs.
The companion then remarks that with this substantial gold find, Injun Joe will no longer need to undertake 'that job.'
Injun Joe frowns, revealing with a wicked glint in his eyes that his motivation for 'that thing' is not robbery, but revenge.
He insists he will still need his companion's assistance and that afterwards, they will proceed to Texas.
They briefly consider reburying the gold, which fills the hidden boys with delight.
However, Injun Joe suddenly exclaims that he almost forgot about the pickaxe having fresh earth on it, a realization that terrifies the boys.
His suspicion aroused, he questions the presence of a pick and shovel with fresh dirt, wondering who brought them and their current whereabouts.
He decides against reburying the treasure in the house, fearing the unknown individuals might discover the disturbed ground.
Instead, he declares they will transport the treasure to his 'den,' specifically 'Number Two—under the cross,' deeming 'Number One' too obvious.
His companion agrees, observing that it is nearly dark enough for them to depart.

events.text_segment:
There’s an old rusty pick over amongst the weeds in the corner the other side of the fireplace—I saw it a minute ago.”
He ran and brought the boys’ pick and shovel. Injun Joe took the pick, looked it over critically, shook his head, muttered something to himself, and then began to use it. The box was soon unearthed. It was not very large; it was iron bound and had been very strong before the slow years had injured it. The men contemplated the treasure awhile in blissful silence.
“Pard, there’s thousands of dollars here,” said Injun Joe.
“’Twas always said that Murrel’s gang used to be around here one summer,” the stranger observed.
“I know it,” said Injun Joe; “and this looks like it, I should say.”
“Now you won’t need to do that job.”
The halfbreed frowned. Said he:
“You don’t know me. Least you don’t know all about that thing. ’Tain’t robbery altogether—it’s revenge!” and a wicked light flamed in his eyes. “I’ll need your help in it. When it’s finished—then Texas. Go home to your Nance and your kids, and stand by till you hear from me.”
“Well—if you say so; what’ll we do with this—bury it again?”
“Yes. [Ravishing delight overhead.] No! by the great Sachem, no! [Profound distress overhead.] I’d nearly forgot. That pick had fresh earth on it! [The boys were sick with terror in a moment.] What business has a pick and a shovel here? What business with fresh earth on them? Who brought them here—and where are they gone? Have you heard anybody?—seen anybody? What! bury it again and leave them to come and see the ground disturbed? Not exactly—not exactly. We’ll take it to my den.”
“Why, of course! Might have thought of that before. You mean Number One?”
“No—Number Two—under the cross. The other place is bad—too common.”
“All right. It’s nearly dark enough to start.”

events.title: Near Discovery Upstairs and the Villains' Departure with Treasure
detailed_summary: Injun Joe moves cautiously from one window to another, peering outside.
He speculates aloud whether the individuals who brought the tools could be hiding upstairs.
This thought causes the boys to lose their breath in terror.
With his hand on his knife, Injun Joe hesitates momentarily before turning towards the staircase.
The boys consider the closet as a hiding place, but their fear renders them immobile.
As Injun Joe's footsteps creak on the stairs, the sheer desperation of their plight momentarily galvanizes the boys' resolve to reach the closet.
However, before they can move, the decayed timbers of the staircase give way, and Injun Joe crashes to the ground amidst the wreckage.
He picks himself up, cursing his misfortune.

His companion argues against investigating upstairs, suggesting that anyone up there should be left alone, and that whoever brought the tools likely fled in fright, mistaking them for supernatural beings.
He points out that darkness is rapidly approaching, which would facilitate their escape.
After some grumbling, Injun Joe concedes that they should use the remaining daylight to prepare for their departure.
Shortly thereafter, as twilight deepens, they exit the house carrying the valuable box and head towards the river.

events.text_segment:
Injun Joe got up and went about from window to window cautiously peeping out. Presently he said:
“Who could have brought those tools here? Do you reckon they can be upstairs?”
The boys’ breath forsook them. Injun Joe put his hand on his knife, halted a moment, undecided, and then turned toward the stairway. The boys thought of the closet, but their strength was gone. The steps came creaking up the stairs—the intolerable distress of the situation woke the stricken resolution of the lads—they were about to spring for the closet, when there was a crash of rotten timbers and Injun Joe landed on the ground amid the debris of the ruined stairway. He gathered himself up cursing, and his comrade said:
“Now what’s the use of all that? If it’s anybody, and they’re up there, let them stay there—who cares? If they want to jump down, now, and get into trouble, who objects? It will be dark in fifteen minutes—and then let them follow us if they want to. I’m willing. In my opinion, whoever hove those things in here caught a sight of us and took us for ghosts or devils or something. I’ll bet they’re running yet.”
Joe grumbled awhile; then he agreed with his friend that what daylight was left ought to be economized in getting things ready for leaving. Shortly afterward they slipped out of the house in the deepening twilight, and moved toward the river with their precious box.

events.title: The Boys' Aftermath: Relief, Regret, and Fearful Resolve
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck emerge from their hiding place, feeling feeble but greatly relieved.
They observe Injun Joe and his companion disappearing through the gaps in the house's log walls.
They have no desire to pursue them, grateful just to be safely on solid ground again and heading towards town.
They walk mostly in silence, overcome with self-blame and regret for having brought the pickaxe and shovel to the haunted house.
They realize that these tools inadvertently alerted Injun Joe to their, or someone's, presence.

They lament that, had it not been for this mistake, Injun Joe would likely have reburied both the silver and the gold, which they could have later retrieved once he had carried out his 'revenge' and departed.
They consider it exceptionally bad luck that their tools were ever brought to that location.
The boys resolve to keep watch for the 'Spaniard' (Injun Joe) upon his return to town to spy for his revenge, with the intention of following him to 'Number Two.'
A terrifying possibility then occurs to Tom: that Injun Joe's planned revenge might be directed at them.
Huck is almost overcome with faintness at this dreadful thought.
As they walk into town, they discuss this fear and try to convince themselves that Injun Joe's target is likely someone else.
They rationalize that, at worst, only Tom might be the target, since he was the one who had testified against Injun Joe in the past.
This reasoning provides very little solace to Tom, who feels that facing such danger alone would be a significant detriment, and that company would be a distinct improvement.

events.text_segment:
Tom and Huck rose up, weak but vastly relieved, and stared after them through the chinks between the logs of the house. Follow? Not they. They were content to reach ground again without broken necks, and take the townward track over the hill. They did not talk much. They were too much absorbed in hating themselves—hating the ill luck that made them take the spade and the pick there. But for that, Injun Joe never would have suspected. He would have hidden the silver with the gold to wait there till his “revenge” was satisfied, and then he would have had the misfortune to find that money turn up missing. Bitter, bitter luck that the tools were ever brought there!
They resolved to keep a lookout for that Spaniard when he should come to town spying out for chances to do his revengeful job, and follow him to “Number Two,” wherever that might be. Then a ghastly thought occurred to Tom.
“Revenge? What if he means us, Huck!”
“Oh, don’t!” said Huck, nearly fainting.
They talked it all over, and as they entered town they agreed to believe that he might possibly mean somebody else—at least that he might at least mean nobody but Tom, since only Tom had testified.

This led him to consider the possibility that the entire grand adventure was merely a dream.
A significant factor supporting this notion was the extraordinary amount of coin he believed he had seen, which seemed far too vast to be genuine.

He had never personally witnessed a sum as large as fifty dollars in one place, and shared the common youthful belief that references to 'hundreds' and 'thousands' were merely figurative expressions, not real monetary amounts.
He had never genuinely imagined that a sum like one hundred dollars could actually exist in physical currency in someone's possession.
If one were to dissect his understanding of hidden treasures, it would likely comprise a small quantity of tangible dimes and a vast, magnificent, yet unattainable collection of dollars.

Suddenly, a brief flash of light emanated from the alley, and Tom burst out, urgently shouting for Huck to run for his life.

events.title: Narrow Escape and Shocking Discovery of Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Huck immediately fled at Tom's warning, the two boys running at top speed until they found refuge in a dilapidated slaughter-house at the village's edge.
Just as they reached cover, a fierce storm broke, and rain began to pour down heavily.
Once Tom regained his breath, he began to recount the harrowing details of his experience inside.
He described how he cautiously tried two keys in the lock, but they made a startling amount of noise and failed to turn.
To his astonishment, upon impulsively trying the doorknob, he discovered the door was unlocked, and it swung open easily.
Stepping inside and removing the towel from the lantern, Tom was horrified to find he had almost stepped directly on Injun Joe, who was lying fast asleep on the floor.

detailed_summary: Huck anxiously inquired if Injun Joe had awakened, but Tom confirmed he remained asleep, likely due to intoxication.

“Lordy, what did you do? Did he wake up?”
“No, never budged. Drunk, I reckon. I just grabbed that towel and started!”
“I’d never ’a’ thought of the towel, I bet!”
“Well, I would. My aunt would make me mighty sick if I lost it.”
“Say, Tom, did you see that box?”
“Huck, I didn’t wait to look around. I didn’t see the box, I didn’t see the cross. I didn’t see anything but a bottle and a tin cup on the floor by Injun Joe; yes, I saw two barrels and lots more bottles in the room. Don’t you see, now, what’s the matter with that ha’nted room?”
“How?”
“Why, it’s ha’nted with whiskey! Maybe all the Temperance Taverns have got a ha’nted room, hey, Huck?”
“Well, I reckon maybe that’s so. Who’d ’a’ thought such a thing? But say, Tom, now’s a mighty good time to get that box, if Injun Joe’s drunk.”
“It is, that! You try it!”

“Well, no—I reckon not.”
“And I reckon not, Huck. Only one bottle alongside of Injun Joe ain’t enough. If there’d been three, he’d be drunk enough and I’d do it.”

detailed_summary: After a period of reflection, Tom proposed a new strategy: they should avoid further attempts to enter the room until they were certain Injun Joe was absent.

He explained his sleeping arrangements in Ben Rogers' hayloft, a privilege granted by Ben and his father's enslaved man, Uncle Jake, with whom Huck had a friendly rapport based on mutual respect and small exchanges of service for food.

There was a long pause for reflection, and then Tom said:
“Lookyhere, Huck, less not try that thing any more till we know Injun Joe’s not in there. It’s too scary. Now, if we watch every night, we’ll be dead sure to see him go out, some time or other, and then we’ll snatch that box quicker’n lightning.”
“Well, I’m agreed. I’ll watch the whole night long, and I’ll do it every night, too, if you’ll do the other part of the job.”
“All right, I will. All you got to do is to trot up Hooper Street a block and maow—and if I’m asleep, you throw some gravel at the window and that’ll fetch me.”
“Agreed, and good as wheat!”
“Now, Huck, the storm’s over, and I’ll go home. It’ll begin to be daylight in a couple of hours. You go back and watch that long, will you?”
“I said I would, Tom, and I will. I’ll ha’nt that tavern every night for a year! I’ll sleep all day and I’ll stand watch all night.”
“That’s all right. Now, where you going to sleep?”
“In Ben Rogers’ hayloft. He lets me, and so does his pap’s nigger man, Uncle Jake. I tote water for Uncle Jake whenever he wants me to, and any time I ask him he gives me a little something to eat if he can spare it. That’s a mighty good nigger, Tom. He likes me, becuz I don’t ever act as if I was above him. Sometime I’ve set right down and eat with him. But you needn’t tell that. A body’s got to do things when he’s awful hungry he wouldn’t want to do as a steady thing.”
“Well, if I don’t want you in the daytime, I’ll let you sleep. I won’t come bothering around. Any time you see something’s up, in the night, just skip right around and maow.”

events.text_segment:
Morning came, eventually, and by ten or eleven o’clock a giddy and rollicking company were gathered at Judge Thatcher’s, and everything was ready for a start. It was not the custom for elderly people to mar the picnics with their presence. The children were considered safe enough under the wings of a few young ladies of eighteen and a few young gentlemen of twenty-three or thereabouts. The old steam ferry-boat was chartered for the occasion; presently the gay throng filed up the main street laden with provision-baskets. Sid was sick and had to miss the fun; Mary remained at home to entertain him. The last thing Mrs. Thatcher said to Becky, was:
“You’ll not get back till late. Perhaps you’d better stay all night with some of the girls that live near the ferry-landing, child.”
“Then I’ll stay with Susy Harper, mamma.”
“Very well. And mind and behave yourself and don’t be any trouble.”
Presently, as they tripped along, Tom said to Becky:
“Say—I’ll tell you what we’ll do. ’Stead of going to Joe Harper’s we’ll climb right up the hill and stop at the Widow Douglas’. She’ll have ice-cream! She has it most every day—dead loads of it. And she’ll be awful glad to have us.”
“Oh, that will be fun!”
Then Becky reflected a moment and said:
“But what will mamma say?”
“How’ll she ever know?”
The girl turned the idea over in her mind, and said reluctantly:
“I reckon it’s wrong—but—”
“But shucks! Your mother won’t know, and so what’s the harm? All she wants is that you’ll be safe; and I bet you she’d ’a’ said go there if she’d ’a’ thought of it. I know she would!”
The Widow Douglas’ splendid hospitality was a tempting bait. It and Tom’s persuasions presently carried the day. So it was decided to say nothing to anybody about the night’s programme. Presently it occurred to Tom that maybe Huck might come this very night and give the signal. The thought took a deal of the spirit out of his anticipations. Still he could not bear to give up the fun at Widow Douglas’. And why should he give it up, he reasoned—the signal did not come the night before, so why should it be any more likely to come tonight? The sure fun of the evening outweighed the uncertain treasure; and, boy-like, he determined to yield to the stronger inclination and not allow himself to think of the box of money another time that day.

events.title: Arrival at the Hollow and Initial Cave Exploration
detailed_summary: The ferryboat journeyed three miles downstream and docked at the entrance of a forested valley.
The group disembarked, and their lively shouts and laughter soon filled the woods and echoed off the nearby cliffs.
After engaging in various activities that left them hot and tired, the picnickers returned to their camp with hearty appetites and began to enjoy the food.
Following the meal, they relaxed and chatted in the shade of large oak trees.
Soon, someone proposed exploring the nearby cave.
The idea was met with universal enthusiasm, and after obtaining bundles of candles, everyone hurried up the hill towards the cave.
The cave's entrance was high on the hillside, shaped like the letter 'A', with its large oak door open.
Inside, a small chamber felt as cold as an icehouse, its limestone walls damp with condensation.
The atmosphere was initially perceived as romantic and mysterious, looking out from the darkness into the sunlit valley.
However, this solemn mood quickly dissipated, and playful activities resumed.
Lighting a candle would trigger a friendly scuffle for it, often resulting in the candle being knocked over or extinguished, followed by laughter and more chasing.
Eventually, the group formed a procession and descended into the main passage of the cave, their flickering lights casting dim illumination on the high rock walls.
This primary passage was relatively narrow, with even narrower crevices branching off frequently.
McDougal's cave was known as a vast, interconnected labyrinth with no discernible end, where one could wander for days without finding an exit.
It was said that no one truly knew the entirety of the cave.
While most young men were familiar with a section of it, they rarely ventured beyond that known area. Tom Sawyer's knowledge of the cave was comparable to anyone else's.

events.text_segment:
Three miles below town the ferryboat stopped at the mouth of a woody hollow and tied up. The crowd swarmed ashore and soon the forest distances and craggy heights echoed far and near with shoutings and laughter. All the different ways of getting hot and tired were gone through with, and by-and-by the rovers straggled back to camp fortified with responsible appetites, and then the destruction of the good things began. After the feast there was a refreshing season of rest and chat in the shade of spreading oaks. By-and-by somebody shouted:
“Who’s ready for the cave?”
Everybody was. Bundles of candles were procured, and straightway there was a general scamper up the hill. The mouth of the cave was up the hillside—an opening shaped like a letter A. Its massive oaken door stood unbarred. Within was a small chamber, chilly as an icehouse, and walled by Nature with solid limestone that was dewy with a cold sweat. It was romantic and mysterious to stand here in the deep gloom and look out upon the green valley shining in the sun. But the impressiveness of the situation quickly wore off, and the romping began again. The moment a candle was lighted there was a general rush upon the owner of it; a struggle and a gallant defence followed, but the candle was soon knocked down or blown out, and then there was a glad clamor of laughter and a new chase. But all things have an end. By-and-by the procession went filing down the steep descent of the main avenue, the flickering rank of lights dimly revealing the lofty walls of rock almost to their point of junction sixty feet overhead. This main avenue was not more than eight or ten feet wide. Every few steps other lofty and still narrower crevices branched from it on either hand—for McDougal’s cave was but a vast labyrinth of crooked aisles that ran into each other and out again and led nowhere. It was said that one might wander days and nights together through its intricate tangle of rifts and chasms, and never find the end of the cave; and that he might go down, and down, and still down, into the earth, and it was just the same—labyrinth under labyrinth, and no end to any of them. No man “knew” the cave. That was an impossible thing. Most of the young men knew a portion of it, and it was not customary to venture much beyond this known portion. Tom Sawyer knew as much of the cave as any one.

events.title: Cave Games, Late Return, and Ferry Departure
detailed_summary: The group advanced about three-quarters of a mile along the main passage of the cave.
Then, smaller groups and pairs began to venture into the side passages, navigating the dark corridors and playfully surprising each other where paths rejoined.
They managed to evade one another for up to half an hour without going beyond the commonly known sections of the cave.
Gradually, one group after another made their way back to the cave entrance, out of breath, joyful, covered in candle wax and clay, and thoroughly pleased with their day's adventure.
They were surprised to discover they had lost track of time and that evening was approaching.

events.title: Huck's Lonely Vigil and Diminishing Hope
detailed_summary: Huck was already at his observation post when he saw the lights of the ferryboat passing the wharf.
He noticed the silence from the boat, attributing it to the passengers being extremely tired.
He briefly wondered about the boat and why it didn't dock, then dismissed it to focus on his task.
The night was becoming overcast and dark.

At ten o'clock, vehicular sounds ceased, lights in houses started going out, and people walking about disappeared; the village settled into sleep, leaving Huck alone with the quiet and his thoughts of ghosts.
When eleven o'clock arrived, the tavern lights were extinguished, plunging everything into darkness.
Huck waited for what felt like an extremely long and tedious period, but nothing occurred.
His confidence began to wane, and he questioned the utility of his vigil, contemplating whether to abandon it and go to sleep.

events.text_segment: Huck was already upon his watch when the ferryboat’s lights went glinting past the wharf. He heard no noise on board, for the young people were as subdued and still as people usually are who are nearly tired to death. He wondered what boat it was, and why she did not stop at the wharf—and then he dropped her out of his mind and put his attention upon his business. The night was growing cloudy and dark. Ten o’clock came, and the noise of vehicles ceased, scattered lights began to wink out, all straggling foot-passengers disappeared, the village betook itself to its slumbers and left the small watcher alone with the silence and the ghosts. Eleven o’clock came, and the tavern lights were put out; darkness everywhere, now. Huck waited what seemed a weary long time, but nothing happened. His faith was weakening. Was there any use? Was there really any use? Why not give it up and turn in?

events.title: Huck Spots Injun Joe and Follows the Villains
detailed_summary: A sound suddenly caught Huck's attention.
He became instantly alert as he heard an alley door close quietly.
He quickly hid behind the corner of a brick store.
Moments later, two men walked past him, one appearing to carry something under his arm, which Huck assumed was the treasure box.
He concluded they were moving the treasure and decided against calling Tom, believing it would be futile as the men would escape.
Instead, he resolved to follow them, relying on the darkness to remain unseen.
Huck silently trailed the men as they walked up river street for three blocks, then turned left onto a cross-street.
They continued straight until they reached the path leading up Cardiff Hill, which they took.
They passed the old Welshman's house halfway up the hill without stopping and kept climbing.
Huck thought they might be heading to bury the treasure in the old quarry.
However, they passed the quarry and continued towards the summit.
They entered a narrow path between tall sumach bushes, disappearing into the darkness.
Huck moved closer, confident they wouldn't see him.
He trotted for a bit, then slowed, worried he was approaching too quickly, and eventually stopped to listen.
He heard no sound except what he thought was his own heartbeat, and then the ominous hoot of an owl.
With no sound of footsteps, he feared he had lost them and was about to rush forward when a man cleared his throat just a few feet away.
Huck's heart leaped, but he regained composure, though he stood there trembling intensely, feeling so weak he thought he might collapse.
He realized his location: within a few steps of the stile leading into Widow Douglas's property, and thought they might bury the treasure there, making it easy to find.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Very well, he thought, let them bury it there; it won’t be hard to find.

events.text_segment:
A noise fell upon his ear. He was all attention in an instant. The alley door closed softly. He sprang to the corner of the brick store. The next moment two men brushed by him, and one seemed to have something under his arm. It must be that box! So they were going to remove the treasure. Why call Tom now? It would be absurd—the men would get away with the box and never be found again. No, he would stick to their wake and follow them; he would trust to the darkness for security from discovery. So communing with himself, Huck stepped out and glided along behind the men, cat-like, with bare feet, allowing them to keep just far enough ahead not to be invisible.
They moved up the river street three blocks, then turned to the left up a crossstreet. They went straight ahead, then, until they came to the path that led up Cardiff Hill; this they took. They passed by the old Welshman’s house, halfway up the hill, without hesitating, and still climbed upward. Good, thought Huck, they will bury it in the old quarry. But they never stopped at the quarry. They passed on, up the summit. They plunged into the narrow path between the tall sumach bushes, and were at once hidden in the gloom. Huck closed up and shortened his distance, now, for they would never be able to see him. He trotted along awhile; then slackened his pace, fearing he was gaining too fast; moved on a piece, then stopped altogether; listened; no sound; none, save that he seemed to hear the beating of his own heart. The hooting of an owl came over the hill—ominous sound! But no footsteps. Heavens, was everything lost! He was about to spring with winged feet, when a man cleared his throat not four feet from him! Huck’s heart shot into his throat, but he swallowed it again; and then he stood there shaking as if a dozen agues had taken charge of him at once, and so weak that he thought he must surely fall to the ground. He knew where he was. He knew he was within five steps of the stile leading into Widow Douglas’ grounds. Very well, he thought, let them bury it there; it won’t be hard to find.

events.title: Huck Overhears Injun Joe's Horrifying Revenge Plan
detailed_summary: Huck then heard a very quiet voice, which he recognized as Injun Joe's, remarking about lights at Widow Douglas's house despite the late hour.
Another voice, that of the stranger from the haunted house, replied that he couldn't see any lights.
A sudden chill struck Huck as he understood that this was the "revenge" Injun Joe had spoken of.
His first instinct was to run, but then he recalled Widow Douglas's past kindness to him and worried that the men intended to murder her.
He wished he had the courage to warn her but knew he was too afraid, as they might catch him.
Injun Joe then directed the stranger's attention, saying a bush was obstructing his view, and pointed out the lights.
The stranger acknowledged the lights and suggested they abandon their plan due to the company.

Injun Joe vehemently refused, stating he was about to leave the country permanently and might not get another chance. He reiterated that he didn't care about her money, which the stranger could have, but was driven by revenge against her late husband.
He recounted how her husband, as justice of the peace, had imprisoned him for vagrancy and, most significantly, had him publicly horsewhipped, an indignity he could not forget.
The stranger begged Injun Joe not to kill the Widow.
Injun Joe clarified his intent was not murder but disfigurement; he planned to slit her nostrils and notch her ears as a form of revenge on a woman.
When the stranger started to object, Injun Joe warned him to keep his opinions to himself for his own safety.
He detailed his plan to tie her to the bed, indifferent to whether she bled to death, and asserted that the stranger must assist him.
He threatened to kill the stranger if he hesitated, and then the Widow as well, ensuring no one would know who committed the crime.
The terrified stranger reluctantly agreed, urging to get it over with quickly.
Injun Joe, however, decided against immediate action due to the lights indicating company, opting to wait until the lights were extinguished.

events.text_segment:
Now there was a voice—a very low voice—Injun Joe’s:
“Damn her, maybe she’s got company—there’s lights, late as it is.”
“I can’t see any.”
This was that stranger’s voice—the stranger of the haunted house. A deadly chill went to Huck’s heart—this, then, was the “revenge” job! His thought was, to fly. Then he remembered that the Widow Douglas had been kind to him more than once, and maybe these men were going to murder her. He wished he dared venture to warn her; but he knew he didn’t dare—they might come and catch him. He thought all this and more in the moment that elapsed between the stranger’s remark and Injun Joe’s next—which was—
“Because the bush is in your way. Now—this way—now you see, don’t you?”
“Yes. Well, there is company there, I reckon. Better give it up.”
“Give it up, and I just leaving this country forever! Give it up and maybe never have another chance. I tell you again, as I’ve told you before, I don’t care for her swag—you may have it. But her husband was rough on me—many times he was rough on me—and mainly he was the justice of the peace that jugged me for a vagrant. And that ain’t all. It ain’t a millionth part of it! He had me horsewhipped!—horsewhipped in front of the jail, like a nigger!—with all the town looking on! Horsewhipped!—do you understand? He took advantage of me and died. But I’ll take it out of her.”
“Oh, don’t kill her! Don’t do that!”
“Kill? Who said anything about killing? I would kill him if he was here; but not her. When you want to get revenge on a woman you don’t kill her—bosh! you go for her looks. You slit her nostrils—you notch her ears like a sow!”
“By God, that’s—”
“Keep your opinion to yourself! It will be safest for you. I’ll tie her to the bed. If she bleeds to death, is that my fault? I’ll not cry, if she does. My friend, you’ll help me in this thing—for my sake—that’s why you’re here—I mightn’t be able alone. If you flinch, I’ll kill you. Do you understand that? And if I have to kill you, I’ll kill her—and then I reckon nobody’ll ever know much about who done this business.”
“Well, if it’s got to be done, let’s get at it. The quicker the better—I’m all in a shiver.”
“Do it now? And company there? Look here—I’ll get suspicious of you, first thing you know. No—we’ll wait till the lights are out—there’s no hurry.

He wished he were brave enough to attempt to warn her, but he knew he didn't dare, fearing they would discover and catch him. He processed all these thoughts and more in the brief interval between the stranger's comment and Injun Joe's next words. Injun Joe explained, "That's because the bush is blocking your view. Now – look over here – now you can see, can't you?" The stranger confirmed, "Yes. Well, it looks like there is company there, I suppose. We should probably abandon this plan." Injun Joe reacted angrily, "Give up now, just as I'm leaving this country forever! Give up and possibly never get another opportunity. I repeat, as I've said before, I don't want her money or valuables – you can have those. But her husband was cruel to me – he was cruel many times – and significantly, he was the justice of the peace who jailed me for being a vagrant. And that's not all. That's not even a tiny fraction of it! He had me publicly whipped with a horsewhip! – whipped in front of the jail, just like a slave! – with everyone in town watching! Horsewhipped! – do you understand? He wronged me and then died. But I will get my retribution from her." The stranger pleaded, "Oh, don't kill her! Please don't do that!" Injun Joe scoffed, "Kill? Who said anything about killing? I would kill him if he were alive and here; but not her. When you seek revenge on a woman, you don't kill her – nonsense! You target her appearance. The stranger, trembling, replied, "Alright, if it has to be done, let's just get it over with. The sooner the better – I'm shaking all over." Injun Joe dismissed the idea, "Do it right now? With company inside? Look here – I'll start to suspect you the moment you suggest things like that. No – we will wait until the lights are out – there's no rush."

events.title: Huck's Daring Escape and Warning to the Welshman
detailed_summary: Anticipating a dreadful silence, Huck began to retreat with extreme caution, balancing precariously with each step.
He took several careful steps back when a twig snapped under his foot.
He froze, holding his breath, but heard no reaction from the men; the stillness was complete, and he was immensely grateful.
He then turned carefully, like a ship maneuvering, and moved quickly but cautiously along the path.
Upon reaching the quarry, he felt safer and ran as fast as he could down the hill until he arrived at the Welshman's house.
He knocked urgently on the door, and soon the old man and his two strong sons appeared at the windows demanding to know who was there and what they wanted.
Huck identified himself and pleaded to be let in quickly, promising to explain everything.
The Welshman, remarking that Huckleberry Finn was not a name that usually opened doors, nevertheless instructed his sons to let him in to see what the matter was.

Once inside, Huck's first words were a plea for them never to reveal that he was the one who told them, expressing fear of being killed, but stating he had to tell because the widow had been kind to him.
The old man, convinced by Huck's earnestness that he had something important to say, promised that no one there would betray him.
Three minutes later, the Welshman and his sons, armed, were heading up the hill, entering the sumach path stealthily with weapons ready. Huck did not go further with them.
He concealed himself behind a large boulder and listened intently.
After a period of tense silence, there was a sudden sound of gunfire and a shout.
Huck did not stay to learn more; he immediately ran away, speeding down the hill as fast as his legs could take him.

events.text_segment:
Huck felt that a silence was going to ensue—a thing still more awful than any amount of murderous talk; so he held his breath and stepped gingerly back; planted his foot carefully and firmly, after balancing, one-legged, in a precarious way and almost toppling over, first on one side and then on the other. He took another step back, with the same elaboration and the same risks; then another and another, and—a twig snapped under his foot! His breath stopped and he listened. There was no sound—the stillness was perfect. His gratitude was measureless. Now he turned in his tracks, between the walls of sumach bushes—turned himself as carefully as if he were a ship—and then stepped quickly but cautiously along. When he emerged at the quarry he felt secure, and so he picked up his nimble heels and flew. Down, down he sped, till he reached the Welshman’s. He banged at the door, and presently the heads of the old man and his two stalwart sons were thrust from windows.
“What’s the row there? Who’s banging? What do you want?”
“Let me in—quick! I’ll tell everything.”
“Why, who are you?”
“Huckleberry Finn—quick, let me in!”
“Huckleberry Finn, indeed! It ain’t a name to open many doors, I judge! But let him in, lads, and let’s see what’s the trouble.”
“Please don’t ever tell I told you,” were Huck’s first words when he got in. “Please don’t—I’d be killed, sure—but the widow’s been good friends to me sometimes, and I want to tell—I will tell if you’ll promise you won’t ever say it was me.”
“By George, he has got something to tell, or he wouldn’t act so!” exclaimed the old man; “out with it and nobody here’ll ever tell, lad.”
Three minutes later the old man and his sons, well armed, were up the hill, and just entering the sumach path on tiptoe, their weapons in their hands. Huck accompanied them no further. He hid behind a great bowlder and fell to listening. There was a lagging, anxious silence, and then all of a sudden there was an explosion of firearms and a cry.
Huck waited for no particulars. He sprang away and sped down the hill as fast as his legs could carry him.

events.text_segment:
As the earliest suspicion of dawn appeared on Sunday morning, Huck came groping up the hill and rapped gently at the old Welshman’s door. The inmates were asleep, but it was a sleep that was set on a hair-trigger, on account of the exciting episode of the night. A call came from a window:
“Who’s there!”
Huck’s scared voice answered in a low tone:
“Please let me in! It’s only Huck Finn!”
“It’s a name that can open this door night or day, lad!—and welcome!”
These were strange words to the vagabond boy’s ears, and the pleasantest he had ever heard. He could not recollect that the closing word had ever been applied in his case before. The door was quickly unlocked, and he entered. Huck was given a seat and the old man and his brace of tall sons speedily dressed themselves.
“Now, my boy, I hope you’re good and hungry, because breakfast will be ready as soon as the sun’s up, and we’ll have a piping hot one, too—make yourself easy about that! I and the boys hoped you’d turn up and stop here last night.”
“I was awful scared,” said Huck, “and I run. I took out when the pistols went off, and I didn’t stop for three mile. I’ve come now becuz I wanted to know about it, you know; and I come before daylight becuz I didn’t want to run across them devils, even if they was dead.”
“Well, poor chap, you do look as if you’d had a hard night of it—but there’s a bed here for you when you’ve had your breakfast. No, they ain’t dead, lad—we are sorry enough for that. You see we knew right where to put our hands on them, by your description; so we crept along on tiptoe till we got within fifteen feet of them—dark as a cellar that sumach path was—and just then I found I was going to sneeze. It was the meanest kind of luck! I tried to keep it back, but no use—’twas bound to come, and it did come! I was in the lead with my pistol raised, and when the sneeze started those scoundrels a-rustling to get out of the path, I sung out, ‘Fire boys!’ and blazed away at the place where the rustling was. So did the boys. But they were off in a jiffy, those villains, and we after them, down through the woods. I judge we never touched them. They fired a shot apiece as they started, but their bullets whizzed by and didn’t do us any harm. As soon as we lost the sound of their feet we quit chasing, and went down and stirred up the constables. They got a posse together, and went off to guard the river bank, and as soon as it is light the sheriff and a gang are going to beat up the woods. My boys will be with them presently. I wish we had some sort of description of those rascals—’twould help a good deal. But you couldn’t see what they were like, in the dark, lad, I suppose?”
“Oh yes; I saw them downtown and follered them.”
“Splendid! Describe them—describe them, my boy!”
“One’s the old deaf and dumb Spaniard that’s ben around here once or twice, and t’other’s a mean-looking, ragged—”
“That’s enough, lad, we know the men! Happened on them in the woods back of the widow’s one day, and they slunk away. Off with you, boys, and tell the sheriff—get your breakfast tomorrow morning!”

events.text_segment:
The Welshman’s sons departed at once. As they were leaving the room Huck sprang up and exclaimed:
“Oh, please don’t tell anybody it was me that blowed on them! Oh, please!”
“All right if you say it, Huck, but you ought to have the credit of what you did.”
“Oh no, no! Please don’t tell!”
When the young men were gone, the old Welshman said:
“They won’t tell—and I won’t. But why don’t you want it known?”
Huck would not explain, further than to say that he already knew too much about one of those men and would not have the man know that he knew anything against him for the whole world—he would be killed for knowing it, sure.
The old man promised secrecy once more, and said:
“How did you come to follow these fellows, lad? Were they looking suspicious?”
Huck was silent while he framed a duly cautious reply. Then he said:
“Well, you see, I’m a kind of a hard lot,—least everybody says so, and I don’t see nothing agin it—and sometimes I can’t sleep much, on account of thinking about it and sort of trying to strike out a new way of doing. That was the way of it last night. I couldn’t sleep, and so I come along upstreet ’bout midnight, a-turning it all over, and when I got to that old shackly brick store by the Temperance Tavern, I backed up agin the wall to have another think. Well, just then along comes these two chaps slipping along close by me, with something under their arm, and I reckoned they’d stole it. One was a-smoking, and t’other one wanted a light; so they stopped right before me and the cigars lit up their faces and I see that the big one was the deaf and dumb Spaniard, by his white whiskers and the patch on his eye, and t’other one was a rusty, ragged-looking devil.”
“Could you see the rags by the light of the cigars?”
This staggered Huck for a moment. Then he said:
“Well, I don’t know—but somehow it seems as if I did.”
“Then they went on, and you—”
“Follered ’em—yes. That was it. I wanted to see what was up—they sneaked along so. I dogged ’em to the widder’s stile, and stood in the dark and heard the ragged one beg for the widder, and the Spaniard swear he’d spile her looks just as I told you and your two—”
“What! The deaf and dumb man said all that!”
Huck had made another terrible mistake! He was trying his best to keep the old man from getting the faintest hint of who the Spaniard might be, and yet his tongue seemed determined to get him into trouble in spite of all he could do. He made several efforts to creep out of his scrape, but the old man’s eye was upon him and he made blunder after blunder. Presently the Welshman said:
“My boy, don’t be afraid of me. I wouldn’t hurt a hair of your head for all the world. No—I’d protect you—I’d protect you. This Spaniard is not deaf and dumb; you’ve let that slip without intending it; you can’t cover that up now. You know something about that Spaniard that you want to keep dark. Now trust me—tell me what it is, and trust me—I won’t betray you.”
Huck looked into the old man’s honest eyes a moment, then bent over and whispered in his ear:
“’Tain’t a Spaniard—it’s Injun Joe!”
The Welshman almost jumped out of his chair. In a moment he said:
“It’s all plain enough, now. When you talked about notching ears and slitting noses I judged that that was your own embellishment, because white men don’t take that sort of revenge. But an Injun! That’s a different matter altogether.”
